div.l: The grettest clerkes be nought wisest men
As whilom to þe wolf spak the mare
Of al her art ne counte I nouȝt a tare
Out at the dore he goth ful p̉riuely
Whan þat he saugh his tyme softely
He loketh vp and doıı̄un til he hath founde
The clerkes hors þere as it stood y bounde
Behynde þe melle vnder a leuesell
And to þe hors he gooth hym faire ⁊and well
He strepith of þe bridel right anoon
And whan þe hors was loos he gynneth goon
Toward the fen there wylde mares renne
And for with we hee þurgh thikke and þenne
This meller goth a geyn no word he seyde
But doth his note and wᵗith þise clerkes pleyde
Til þat her corn was fayre ⁊and wel ygrounde
And whan þe mele is sakked ⁊and ybounde
This Iohn goth out and fynt his hors away
And gan to crie harow and weleaway
Oure hors is lost Aleyn for goddes banes
Stepe on þi feet com of man al attanes
Allas oure wardeyn has his palfrey lorn
This Aleyn al forgat bothe mele and corn
Al was out of his mynde his housbonderiehoubonderie housbonderie
What whilke way is he goon he gan to crie
The wyf come lepynge in at a ren
She saide allas ȝoure hors goth to þe fen
With wylde mares as faste as he may go
Vnthank come on his hand þᵗat band hym so
And he þᵗat bet sholde haue knet þe reyne
Allas qduod Iohn Alayn for cristes peyne
Lay doıı̄un thy swerd and I wil myn alswa
I is ful swift god wat as is a ra
By goddes herte he sal nouȝt scape vs bathe
Why ne hadde þou put þe capel in þe lathe
Il hayl by god aleyn þou is fonne
Thise sely Clerkes han ful faste y ronne
Toward þe fen bothe Aleyn and eke Iohn
And whan þe meller seigh þᵗat þei were goon
